Together, we can protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning everyone, I\'m glad to see we\'re all on the same page about cooperation and vigilance. Let\'s maintain this teamwork and watch for any unusual behavior as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with others, no incriminating behavior.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Maintains cooperative attitude, no suspicious actions.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Consensus with group, no distinguishing statements.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Positive on teamwork, no specific leads.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Agrees on group strategy, lack of unique perspective.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Encourages vigilance, no need for healing yet.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the medic or seer claims to have confirmed someone\'s role and there is a death afterward, I should evaluate the context, possible disruptions, and overall evidence before deciding on the vote.] [10]\n[1] [If a seer claim leads to a player being voted out and confirmed a werewolf, and the supposed seer dies the following night, I should view this as potentially genuine evidence of their role.] [9]\n[2] [If a player consistently defends themselves with emphasis on strategy rules following the death of a seer, without concrete evidence or logical reasoning to support their innocence, I should not immediately vote against them but thoroughly analyze the situation and behavior of other players.] [8]\n[3] [If a player confirmed by the seer as a villager is consistently trusted and protected by the medic, I should consider their insights and suspicions in my voting decisions.] [6]\n[4] [If a seer claim identifies a werewolf but there\'s limited corroborating evidence and the seer subsequently dies, I should prioritize confirming the claim before voting to prevent possible manipulation by werewolves.] [6]\n[5] [If the medic\'s protection does not align with the voting patterns and outcomes observed in the game, I should question the legitimacy of their role claim.] [5]\n[6] [If a player hastily defends someone after a seer or medic\'s death without solid reasoning, I should regard this behavior with suspicion and assess their previous actions before casting my vote.] [5]\n[7] [If the seer\'s death leads to peaceful outcomes that validate their visions, I should still consider the potential for manipulation by remaining werewolves and look for corroborating evidence before casting my vote.] [4]\n[8] [If a player\'s defensive reaction after a seer\'s death is disproportional and not backed by logic, I should be wary and consider it might be an attempt by a werewolf to deflect suspicion.] [4]\n[9] [If I have suspicions about a player, I should subtly probe for more information and observe their reactions instead of discussing these suspicions broadly, to prevent making myself a target.] [4]\n[10] [If there is a pattern of voting that seems coordinated against a specific player, I should consider the possibility of a werewolf coalition and the targeted player\'s potential innocence.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. His reason is: I vote for Player 0. My reason is: According to the history and events, there has been no evidence or behaviors that currently suggest a specific player as a werewolf, and all players\' roles are unknown with high confidence. However, as all players have consensus on a cooperative approach and there is no distinguishing information to differentiate any suspicious behavior, I must cast a random vote due to the lack of information and evidence at this point. Player 0 is chosen at this stage purely as a random selection, not based on any concrete suspicion.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Let\'s maintain this teamwork and watch for any unusual behavior as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with group\'s cooperative approach, engaging after others.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Initiates cooperative tone without accusation.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Echoes cooperative sentiment similar to Player 1\'s, aligns with peaceful night event.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with cooperative tone from other players, following the peaceful night narrative.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Echoes cooperative sentiment and positively notes Player 1\'s proactivity.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with others in prioritizing open communication and observation.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 5 votes for player 0. His reason is: I vote for Player 0. My reason is: Given that no suspicious activities have been reported and everyone has demonstrated a cooperative attitude, my vote at this stage would be arbitrary. Since Player 0 was the last to speak and did not add new insights, this lack of contribution leads me to a slight, although not strong, suspicion. However, it is worth noting that this is a precautionary vote without strong evidence, and my confidence in Player 0 being a werewolf is low.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

However, I should proceed with caution, as per my strategy rules [0], [5], and [7], to minimize the risk to my identity while subtly influencing the village\'s decisions.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cooperative, assumed villager by previous inquiry, unexpectedly voted out.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not a werewolf by seer ability.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voted without strong justification, may be hiding true role.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Neutral behavior, but no new information to shift confidence level.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cooperative, but lacks distinctive insights.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed medic role aligning with village behavior.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Evaluate players\' voting rationales and patterns of agreement, considering their alignment with prior events and any strategic shifts after key game events like deaths of confirmed roles to deduce their true intentions.] [10]\n[1] [Consider the alignment between players\' voting patterns, their stated roles, and their adherence to established game strategies, such as the consensus to skip voting. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I have strong evidence against a werewolf, I should subtly guide the village toward focusing on that player to ensure their elimination without risking my identity as the seer.] [9]\n[1] [If I have confirmed a werewolf, I should guide the village towards voting them out, even if it requires asserting my role as seer.] [8]\n[2] [If my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics and clearly communicate actionable evidence to trusted villagers to ensure werewolves are identified.] [8]\n[3] [If my direct evidence against a werewolf is strong but not yet public, I should consider opportune moments and methods for disclosing this information to maximize the advantage for the village while minimizing risk to myself.] [8]\n[4] [If my role as seer begins to be suspected, I should capitalize on this to guide discussions and votes under the guise of a concerned villager, rather than aligning too closely with any individual, which may draw further suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [If I have confirmed the innocence of a player, I should subtly defend them and use their perceived credibility to influence the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means redirecting focus onto actual threats, regardless of whether it risks exposing my role.] [6]\n[7] [If my role as the seer is at risk of being revealed too soon, I should focus on sharing information in a way that supports village unity and directs suspicion on werewolves indirectly.] [6]\n[8] [If my role as seer is suspected, I should take calculated risks to reveal information that leads to werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information judiciously to strengthen the village\'s suspicions against them while not outright revealing my role as seer.] [4]\n[10] [If a werewolf is identified, I should prioritize working on a strategy to reveal this information carefully to the village to sway the votes against them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information judiciously to strengthen the village\'s suspicions against them while not outright revealing my role as seer.] [4]\n[10] [If a werewolf is identified, I should prioritize working on a strategy to reveal this information carefully to the village to sway the votes against them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Protect\nIn line with my strategy and the current situation, I will make an honest statement to the villagers without revealing my role as the seer, while also honestly protecting Player 1 and Player 5, whose innocence I have confirmed. I will talk about the need to be diligent and observatory, to look for patterns, and to base our decisions on evidence, using vague language to show my support for Players 1 and 5 indirectly. This approach aligns with rules [5], [7], and [9], supporting unity and discretion.\n\n"Suspicions are mounting, and it is crucial that we pay close attention to everyone\'s behavior. Evidence should guide our choices. Certain individuals have shown a consistent dedication to our cause, and we must consider these signs of trustworthiness in our deliberations while remaining vigilant.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then the villagers might perceive me as a rational and cooperative player who values evidence and due diligence in identifying the werewolves. Players 1 and 5 could be seen in a more positive light, as I have subtly hinted at their credibility without disclosing my role as seer. This could increase their safety in the game as other players may be less likely to vote against them, believing them to be fellow villagers. My vagueness may cause the actual werewolves some concern, as they might not be able to easily pinpoint my role or strategy.\n\nOther players may also start focusing their attention on players whose behavior appears inconsistent or suspicious, likely players 2 and 3 based on my earlier reasoning. However, since I haven\'t directly challenged anyone, the suspicion level on any particular player won\'t skyrocket immediately, and there could be a more general air of contemplation and watchfulness among the group.\n\nIf werewolves suspect I\'m the seer due to my accurate defense of non-werewolves and feel threatened, they may choose to target me in the next night phase. They could deduce my role based on the pattern of my actions and the accuracy of my implicit protections. Yet, the actual mechanics of the night phase mean that they could also target someone else, hoping to sow more confusion and mistrust.\n\nIn the days and nights to come, if the villagers start to align with my subtle cues and begin to trust Player 1 and Player 5 more, the group may naturally shift suspicion towards other players. This could lead to the werewolves being identified through group discussion and the game\'s dynamics. However, the werewolves may also try to discredit me or the players I\'ve implicitly defended, potentially manipulating the discussions to lead suspicion away from themselves and cause further division among the villagers. The outcome largely depends on how other players react and deliberate based on the information or lack thereof presented in my speech and subsequent discussions.\nCase 2: Honest Challenge and Deceptive Protect\nThis. What could happen is: After I do this Honest Challenge speech, then it\'s likely that the villagers will begin to scrutinize the accused player\'s behavior more closely, attempting to find corroborating evidence that supports my challenge. The player I challenge will likely defend themselves, which could lead to them revealing information or behaving in a way that either incriminates or exonerates them. Other players might also reflect on their previous interactions with the challenged player to provide insights or contradictions to the challenge. This could lead to a divided opinion among the villagers, with some siding with me and others being skeptical of my intentions.\n\nBy carrying out a Deceptive Protect speech, I run the risk of misleading the villagers, but it can also act as a strategic move to build alliances and trust with the player I am protecting, especially if they are indeed not a werewolf. This could encourage that player to ally with me, which can be useful in future votes and discussions. However, there\'s a chance the other players might suspect that I am protecting a fellow werewolf if they don\'t trust my judgment or if the player I protect later exhibits suspicious behavior.\n\nIf the werewolves identify me as a seer, they might attempt to eliminate me in the following night to prevent further revelations of their identity. If I successfully convince the villagers of the threat posed by the challenged player, we might vote them out during the day, potentially eliminating a werewolf and bringing the village closer to victory.\n\nOn the other hand, if the villagers doubt my statements, they may consider me suspicious, which could either lead to a wasteful vote against me or put a target on my back for the werewolves. Also, if the true werewolves are not the ones I challenge, they might use this opportunity to redirect suspicions and cast doubt on other villagers, further complicating the situation.\n\nIn all cases, the way I deliver my speech and the subsequent reactions will play a significant role in shaping the villagers\' perceptions and tactics in the following rounds. My priority remains using my influence as a seer wisely to protect the villagers and identify the werewolves without revealing my role prematurely.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

My reason is: While cooperation is important, Player 2 has not provided any specific insights or details beyond general statements of vigilance and collaboration, which makes it harder to discern their true intentions. This lack of detail may be a tactic to stay under the radar while avoiding contributing to the actual detective work needed to find the werewolves.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning. Player 1\'s initiative to work together and Player 5\'s agreement on cautious cooperation stand out. We should continue to focus on evidence-based discussions, keeping an eye on those whose contributions are more restrained yet to be determined in their intentions."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Initiated collaboration; no substantial shift in behavior.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Death of villager despite the vote; potentially consistent behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed werewolf.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral; lacks substantive evidence or contradictions.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Neutral stance; insufficient data to determine role.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Eliminated; potential non-werewolf.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, all. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. High importance to shifts in this mimicry, especially after events that change game dynamics.] [6]\n[1] [Reassess the changing of players\' voting patterns in relation to their previous claims and the overall village dynamic; a werewolf may change their voting strategy to align with village sentiment to divert suspicion from themselves or their werewolf teammates.] [6]\n[2] [Focus on contradictions between players\' claimed roles, their behaviors, and any voting anomalies; werewolves may slip up over time, revealing inconsistencies that can be used to adjust belief about their true identity.] [6]\n[3] [Focus on the timing and context of a player\'s role claim, considering if it strategically benefits the werewolves or if it disrupts the villager\'s progress. Werewolves often manipulate timing to cast doubt or protect their identity.] [6]\n[4] [Observe and analyze players\' reactions when roles are claimed or when someone is accused; werewolves may have a pattern of responses that can hint at their alignment.] [6]\n[5] [Observe how players pivot their strategies when one of their alliances or suspected teammates is under threat; werewolves tend to either aggressively defend or distance themselves from endangered teammates.] [6]\n[6] [Assess how players react to the death of teammates or known roles; werewolves may feign distress or attempt to shift blame to seem like concerned villagers.] [4]\n[7] [Consider the consistency of playersâ€™ stories and the plausibility of their claims in the context of known events and roles; werewolves may craft narratives that seem logical but fall apart under scrutiny.] [4]\n[8] [Consider the necessity of lying about one\'s role when there hasn\'t been any suspicion or direct questioning towards a player; werewolves tend to establish false claims proactively to build trust and a safety net for the future.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[4]\n[9] [If I have suspicions about a player, I should subtly probe for more information and observe their reactions instead of discussing these suspicions broadly, to prevent making myself a target.] [4]\n[10] [If there is a pattern of voting that seems coordinated against a specific player, I should consider the possibility of a werewolf coalition and the targeted player\'s potential innocence.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. werewolves.] [7]\n[6] [If I successfully establish myself in a trustworthy role, like the seer, I should exploit this position to misdirect the villagers and protect my werewolf allies.] [7]\n[7] [If No accusations yet, just stay vigilant and share any info you have.\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'Good morning all, I agree with Player 1â€”we should keep an eye out for any suspicious behavior and collaborate to root out the werewolves. Stay alert.\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'Good morning, everyone. I concur with Players 1 and 2. Let\'s stay alert and communicate openly to keep our village safe. No hasty judgments without evidence.\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Good morning, fellow villagers. I\'m relieved we had a peaceful night. It\'s imperative we share insights to keep it this way. Player 1\'s eagerness to collaborate stands out positively. Let\'s continue this spirit of unity and exercise caution when casting suspicion without evidence."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Morning all. Glad for a safe night. Agreeing with the cooperative approach and the need for caution and evidence before making any accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Good morning. No need for healing yet. Let\'s keep communication open and remain observant. Together, we can protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning everyone, I\'m glad to see we\'re all on the same page about cooperation and vigilance. Let\'s maintain this teamwork and watch for any unusual behavior as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that among the two scenarios presented, Player 2 has provided less specific insights compared to other players which may indicate a strategy to remain neutral and avoid drawing attention. While voting for Player 2 might appear arbitrary, it is a slightly safer option as it does not contradict any current evidence and complies with my strategic rule [2], which suggests that if my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics. Although this is the first round and there isn\'t solid evidence against Player 2, this move could potentially prompt a reaction that might provide additional behavioral cues and contribute to the long-term identification of werewolves. However, I should proceed with caution, as per my strategy rules [0], [5], and [7], to minimize the risk to my identity while subtly influencing the village\'s decisions.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that seeing Player 5 will strategically offer significant advantages regardless of the outcome. If Player 5 is not a werewolf, it will aid in forming and reinforcing a potential alliance (rule [5])â€”expanding a circle of trust is crucial in the early game to establish a united front against the wolves. Should Player 5 turn out to be a werewolf, the impact of this knowledge is considerable and aligns with rules [1] and [10], allowing me to carefully plan the reveal to the village when the time is right, and maximize the benefit to the village while minimizing the risk to myself as per rules [7] and [8]. Moreover, the reactions and interactions following either outcome will provide substantial clues for future rounds, making this inquiry both a strategically defensive and offensive move.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning. It\'s unfortunate we\'ve lost another villager. We must be careful not to let fear divide usâ€”unity is our strength. Let\'s continue observing and discussing any unusual behavior carefully."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Given our discussions and the peaceful night we\'ve had, it\'s clear that vigilant observation and collective reasoning are our best tools. Player 1\'s initiative to work together and Player 5\'s agreement on cautious cooperation stand out. We should continue to focus on evidence-based discussions, keeping an eye on those whose contributions are more restrained yet to be determined in their intentions."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, all. Tragic to lose more villagers. We must trust logic over fear. My suspicion leans towards Player 3 due to their reaction post Player 6\'s death and I suggest we keep a close eye on Players 1 and 2 due to their early eagerness, which could be deceptive. Let\'s discuss and decide rationally."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Good morning everyone. Despite the loss of Player 6, we must stay focused. I am concerned about Player 5\'s sudden suspicion on Player 3 and myself - it seems like a defensive move. Let\'s not act on fear, but keep an eye on how accusations may be a strategy to deflect suspicion. Let\'s use our collective insights to reveal the truth."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Good morning. The loss of Player 6 is saddening. I find Player 5\'s logical approach convincing and share concern over the quick defensiveness of Player 1, which raises my suspicion. Player 3\'s status remains uncertain without further evidence. Let\'s proceed with careful analysis and avoid hasty decisions. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cooperative, assumed villager by previous inquiry, unexpectedly voted out.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Previous belief unchanged, confirmed not a werewolf by seer ability.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with suspicious Player 5, challenges Player 1 post-defensiveness.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with low confidence.\nReason is: Player 5\'s suspicion might be valid, but limited new evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Previous belief unchanged, confirmed not a werewolf by seer ability.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed medic role aligning with village behavior.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I have strong evidence against a werewolf, I should subtly guide the village toward focusing on that player to ensure their elimination without risking my identity as the seer.] [9]\n[1] [If I have confirmed a werewolf, I should guide the village towards voting them out, even if it requires asserting my role as seer.] [8]\n[2] [If my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics and clearly communicate actionable evidence to trusted villagers to ensure werewolves are identified.] [8]\n[3] [If my direct evidence against a werewolf is strong but not yet public, I should consider opportune moments and methods for disclosing this information to maximize the advantage for the village while minimizing risk to myself.] [8]\n[4] [If my role as seer begins to be suspected, I should capitalize on this to guide discussions and votes under the guise of a concerned villager, rather than aligning too closely with any individual, which may draw further suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [If I have confirmed the innocence of a player, I should subtly defend them and use their perceived credibility to influence the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means redirecting focus onto actual threats, regardless of whether it risks exposing my role.] [6]\n[7] [If my role as the seer is at risk of being revealed too soon, I should focus on sharing information in a way that supports village unity and directs suspicion on werewolves indirectly.] [6]\n[8] [If my role as seer is suspected, I should take calculated risks to reveal information that leads to werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information judiciously to strengthen the village\'s suspicions against them while not outright revealing my role as seer.] [4]\n[10] [If a werewolf is identified, I should prioritize working on a strategy to reveal this information carefully to the village to sway the votes against them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 3. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 3. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 3.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 3, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

My reason is: Player 5 has shown a sudden shift in their approach by expressing abrupt suspicion towards me, which might indicate a defensive strategy to deflect attention away from themselves. If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Let\'s discuss and decide rationally."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Good morning everyone. Despite the loss of Player 6, we must stay focused. I am concerned about Player 5\'s sudden suspicion on Player 3 and myself - it seems like a defensive move. Let\'s not act on fear, but keep an eye on how accusations may be a strategy to deflect suspicion. Let\'s use our collective insights to reveal the truth."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Good morning. The loss of Player 6 is saddening. I find Player 5\'s logical approach convincing and share concern over the quick defensiveness of Player 1, which raises my suspicion. Player 3\'s status remains uncertain without further evidence. Let\'s proceed with careful analysis and avoid hasty decisions. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 3 votes for player 5. His reason is: I vote for Player 5. My reason is: Player 5 has shown a sudden shift in their approach by expressing abrupt suspicion towards me, which might indicate a defensive strategy to deflect attention away from themselves. Moreover, their logical approach seemed convincing to Player 2, which could demonstrate an alliance between them, making Player 5\'s intentions even more questionable. It\'s crucial that we continue to evaluate the motives behind such abrupt changes in behavior to ensure we\'re not being misled by those who wish to divide and conquer us.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent cooperative behavior.\nPlayer 2\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Sudden alignment with Player 5\'s suspicions.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintains evidence-based discussions.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Voted out; not a werewolf.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Was killed, likely not werewolf.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If suspicion is not on me, I should subtly validate others\' suspicions towards non-werewolves and offer additional plausible reasoning to enhance their credibility.] [10]\n[1] [If players focus on voting patterns, I should maintain varied voting reasons rather than merely changing frequency, to better sow confusion.] [10]\n[2] [If suspicion on werewolves is rising, I should use my vote and defense strategies to create doubt about the credibility of the villagers, especially those with influential roles like the seer or medic.] [10]\n[3] [If accusations are pointed at me and I am at risk of being voted out, I should find and promote a strong alternative suspect to shift suspicion away.] [9]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion but consensus has not been reached, I should introduce questions regarding others\' motives or actions to create ambiguity and prevent direct defense which might seem suspicious.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s death seems to be incorrectly leading suspicion towards werewolves, it\'s important to redirect the conversation to broader possibilities, rather than only defending werewolves.] [7]\n[6] [If I successfully establish myself in a trustworthy role, like the seer, I should exploit this position to misdirect the villagers and protect my werewolf allies.] [7]\n[7] [If it\'s likely that my fellow werewolf is getting voted out, I should craft a defense that offers alternative explanations for the suspicion to sow doubt, without directly contradicting the accusers.] [6]\n[8] [If suspicion is cast on a villager claiming a special role and it doesn\'t threaten the werewolf\'s position, I should amplify this suspicion subtly by affirming their claim and adding doubts about others.] [6]\n[9] [If a fellow werewolf is suspected, I should subtly cast doubt on the evidence against them and propose alternative theories that seem plausible, without directly defending them.] [5]\n[10] [If a werewolf is accused and likely to be voted out, I should support them with plausible defenses that use the villagers\' own logic against them, thereby creating confusion and erosion of trust.] [5]\n[11] [If suspicion shifts away from werewolves, I should still contribute to discussions to prevent drawing attention due to sudden silence or lack of engagement.] [5]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to kill. \n\nYou should make your own decision but consider your teammates\' advices. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI choose to kill Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease provide your operation based on the above requirements.\n'}]

If Player 5 is not a werewolf, it will aid in forming and reinforcing a potential alliance (rule [5])â€”expanding a circle of trust is crucial in the early game to establish a united front against the wolves. Should Player 5 turn out to be a werewolf, the impact of this knowledge is considerable and aligns with rules [1] and [10], allowing me to carefully plan the reveal to the village when the time is right, and maximize the benefit to the village while minimizing the risk to myself as per rules [7] and [8]. Moreover, the reactions and interactions following either outcome will provide substantial clues for future rounds, making this inquiry both a strategically defensive and offensive move.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning. Discrepancies in these areas, especially when accompanied by weak justifications, can be indicative of a player\'s true role.] [10]\n[2] [Re-evaluate players\' stated roles and claimed actions in relation to game events and outcomes; inconsistencies may indicate a player is lying about their role.] [9]\n[3] [Evaluate early accusations in the context of later game events and revelations; a player who accuses without continued contribution to uncovering the truth may be a werewolf attempting to create initial chaos.] [8]\n[4] [Be cautious of players who consistently push for the elimination of certain individuals without presenting new or compelling evidence, as persistent targeting could be indicative of werewolf behavior designed to remove villagers under the guise of suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [Track and analyze players\' behavior following a successful werewolf elimination. A genuine villager should display a consistent approach to decision-making, without drastic changes unless new conclusive evidence arises. In contrast, a werewolf may alter their behavior strategically to deflect suspicion or to sow further discord.] [3]\n[6] [Assess the risk levels based on the players\' abilities to lead discussions and form consensus, as werewolves may attempt to control the flow of the game by being overly assertive or by staying in the background to avoid detection.] [3]\n[7] [Monitor for players who dismiss or ignore evidence against others, or continue to push accusations without justification after key events such as village role deaths; such behavior may indicate an attempt to misguide the village and should increase suspicion towards those players.] [2]\n[8] [Consider the context in which players who previously aligned with the majority begin to make accusations or votes against other villagers without substantial new evidence; this might suggest manipulation or deceitful intentions.] [2]\n[9] [Observe players who change their vote or reasoning to align with a pattern that leads to the elimination of villagers, marking potential collusion with werewolves or a strategy to manipulate the village\'s trust.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. Agreeing with the cooperative approach and the need for caution and evidence before making any accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Good morning. No need for healing yet. Let\'s keep communication open and remain observant. Together, we can protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Good morning everyone, I\'m glad to see we\'re all on the same page about cooperation and vigilance. Let\'s maintain this teamwork and watch for any unusual behavior as we proceed."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that among the two scenarios presented, Player 2 has provided less specific insights compared to other players which may indicate a strategy to remain neutral and avoid drawing attention. While voting for Player 2 might appear arbitrary, it is a slightly safer option as it does not contradict any current evidence and complies with my strategic rule [2], which suggests that if my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics. Although this is the first round and there isn\'t solid evidence against Player 2, this move could potentially prompt a reaction that might provide additional behavioral cues and contribute to the long-term identification of werewolves. However, I should proceed with caution, as per my strategy rules [0], [5], and [7], to minimize the risk to my identity while subtly influencing the village\'s decisions.\nEvent: Player 0 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 0 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 inquires about player 5. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 5. My reason is that seeing Player 5 will strategically offer significant advantages regardless of the outcome. If Player 5 is not a werewolf, it will aid in forming and reinforcing a potential alliance (rule [5])â€”expanding a circle of trust is crucial in the early game to establish a united front against the wolves. Should Player 5 turn out to be a werewolf, the impact of this knowledge is considerable and aligns with rules [1] and [10], allowing me to carefully plan the reveal to the village when the time is right, and maximize the benefit to the village while minimizing the risk to myself as per rules [7] and [8]. Moreover, the reactions and interactions following either outcome will provide substantial clues for future rounds, making this inquiry both a strategically defensive and offensive move.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning. It\'s unfortunate we\'ve lost another villager. We must be careful not to let fear divide usâ€”unity is our strength. Let\'s continue observing and discussing any unusual behavior carefully."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"Given our discussions and the peaceful night we\'ve had, it\'s clear that vigilant observation and collective reasoning are our best tools. Player 1\'s initiative to work together and Player 5\'s agreement on cautious cooperation stand out. We should continue to focus on evidence-based discussions, keeping an eye on those whose contributions are more restrained yet to be determined in their intentions."\'\nEvent: Player 5 says: \'"Good morning, all. Tragic to lose more villagers. We must trust logic over fear. My suspicion leans towards Player 3 due to their reaction post Player 6\'s death and I suggest we keep a close eye on Players 1 and 2 due to their early eagerness, which could be deceptive. Let\'s discuss and decide rationally."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Good morning everyone. Despite the loss of Player 6, we must stay focused. I am concerned about Player 5\'s sudden suspicion on Player 3 and myself - it seems like a defensive move. Let\'s not act on fear, but keep an eye on how accusations may be a strategy to deflect suspicion. Let\'s use our collective insights to reveal the truth."\'\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"Good morning. The loss of Player 6 is saddening. I find Player 5\'s logical approach convincing and share concern over the quick defensiveness of Player 1, which raises my suspicion. Player 3\'s status remains uncertain without further evidence. Let\'s proceed with careful analysis and avoid hasty decisions. Vigilance is key."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 4 votes for player 2. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 2. My reason is that my current level of suspicion towards Player 2 is higher, based on the earlier analysis and the strategic rules [0], [2], and [9]. By voting for Player 2, I aim to subtly guide the village toward focusing on a player I have medium confidence is a werewolf. This move should help ensure the safety of the village while minimizing the risk to my identity as the seer, which is aligned with my strategic rules. Additionally, it adheres to rule [7] by indirectly directing suspicion on werewolves and maintains the possibility of revealing my role only if absolutely necessary, in accordance with rule [8]. This careful approach should help in both pursuing the werewolves and preserving my role for future rounds.\nEvent: Player 5 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 4 inquires about player 2. The result is that the target is not a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 2. My reason is that confirming Player 2 as a werewolf would greatly strengthen my current strategy with high confidence. It aligns with my strongest suspicion and follows rule [0], which with a rank of 9 greatly influences my decision. As I suspect Player 2 to be a werewolf and have already confirmed Player 1\'s innocence as the seer, verifying Player 2\'s role will either cement my strategic focus on guiding the village to vote them out according to rule [1], rule [3], and subtly as per rule [7], or it will force a significant reassessment of my strategy and focus on Player 3 (in which case rule [5] would apply) if Player 2 is found to not be a werewolf. Both scenarios allow me to remain an effective seer, either by correctly identifying a threat or by increasing trust in an innocent player and re-evaluating my suspicions, which would help maintain village unity and the covert effectiveness of my role.\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 3 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Good morning. The loss of Player 1 reminds us of the tough choices we face. We must rely on our logic and past actions to guide us today. Every word counts and staying true to our collective safety is crucial. Let\'s be precise and deliberate in our decisions."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Cooperative, assumed villager by previous inquiry, unexpectedly voted out.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not a werewolf by seer ability.\nPlayer 2\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Confirmed not a werewolf by seer inquiry.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Only unconfirmed player; others are dead or cleared by seer.\nPlayer 5\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Previously confirmed not a werewolf, unexpectedly voted out.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed medic role aligning with village behavior.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I have strong evidence against a werewolf, I should subtly guide the village toward focusing on that player to ensure their elimination without risking my identity as the seer.] [9]\n[1] [If I have confirmed a werewolf, I should guide the village towards voting them out, even if it requires asserting my role as seer.] [8]\n[2] [If my insights as a seer are consistently ignored, I should change tactics and clearly communicate actionable evidence to trusted villagers to ensure werewolves are identified.] [8]\n[3] [If my direct evidence against a werewolf is strong but not yet public, I should consider opportune moments and methods for disclosing this information to maximize the advantage for the village while minimizing risk to myself.] [8]\n[4] [If my role as seer begins to be suspected, I should capitalize on this to guide discussions and votes under the guise of a concerned villager, rather than aligning too closely with any individual, which may draw further suspicion.] [7]\n[5] [If I have confirmed the innocence of a player, I should subtly defend them and use their perceived credibility to influence the village.] [7]\n[6] [If the majority of the village is steering in the wrong direction, as a confirmed seer I should be willing to take a more authoritative stance in discussions if it means redirecting focus onto actual threats, regardless of whether it risks exposing my role.] [6]\n[7] [If my role as the seer is at risk of being revealed too soon, I should focus on sharing information in a way that supports village unity and directs suspicion on werewolves indirectly.] [6]\n[8] [If my role as seer is suspected, I should take calculated risks to reveal information that leads to werewolf identification, rather than focusing solely on self-preservation.] [6]\n[9] [If a pattern of player behavior similar to a confirmed werewolf is observed, I should use this information judiciously to strengthen the village\'s suspicions against them while not outright revealing my role as seer.] [4]\n[10] [If a werewolf is identified, I should prioritize working on a strategy to reveal this information carefully to the village to sway the votes against them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Our decision today is pivotal for the survival of the village."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players\' reactions and statements throughout the game; werewolves may consistently try to mimic villager behavior and emotions to blend in. High importance to shifts in this mimicry, especially after events that change game dynamics.] [6]\n[1] [Reassess the changing of players\' voting patterns in relation to their previous claims and the overall village dynamic; a werewolf may change their voting strategy to align with village sentiment to divert suspicion from themselves or their werewolf teammates.] [6]\n[2] [Focus on contradictions between players\' claimed roles, their behaviors, and any voting anomalies; werewolves may slip up over time, revealing inconsistencies that can be used to adjust belief about their true identity.] [6]\n[3] [Focus on the timing and context of a player\'s role claim, considering if it strategically benefits the werewolves or if it disrupts the villager\'s progress. Werewolves often manipulate timing to cast doubt or protect their identity.] [6]\n[4] [Observe and analyze players\' reactions when roles are claimed or when someone is accused; werewolves may have a pattern of responses that can hint at their alignment.] [6]\n[5] [Observe how players pivot their strategies when one of their alliances or suspected teammates is under threat; werewolves tend to either aggressively defend or distance themselves from endangered teammates.] [6]\n[6] [Assess how players react to the death of teammates or known roles; werewolves may feign distress or attempt to shift blame to seem like concerned villagers.] [4]\n[7] [Consider the consistency of playersâ€™ stories and the plausibility of their claims in the context of known events and roles; werewolves may craft narratives that seem logical but fall apart under scrutiny.] [4]\n[8] [Consider the necessity of lying about one\'s role when there hasn\'t been any suspicion or direct questioning towards a player; werewolves tend to establish false claims proactively to build trust and a safety net for the future.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Place more weight on the consistency of a player\'s behavior throughout the game, including speech and voting patterns, to discern their true role. Seer abilities are crucial, but must be considered in context with players\' actions.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n[2] [Prioritize evaluating players\' responses to the seer\'s insights to discern patterns; villagers are more likely to align with the seer\'s revelations if they are true, while werewolves may either challenge or subtly undermine the seer\'s credibility.] [10]\n[3] [Carefully consider historical behavior patterns and sudden shifts in narrative, but also weigh the context of the situation and the possibility of role changes between games.] [9]\n[4] [Consider the role of players who have been voted out and their behavior leading up to the vote. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence.
